ground_truth.answer: Yes, H-1B holders can pursue permanent residence through employment-based petitions while maintaining H-1B status.

questions.question: What happens if H1B is denied after F1 expires?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, if an F-1 student's status expires and their H-1B petition is denied, they will have a 60-day grace period to depart the United States, unless the denial was due to a status violation, misrepresentation, or fraud (Source 4 and Source 5). 

However, if the H-1B petition was denied after the F-1 student's status had already expired, but they had a pending H-1B petition and were in a period of authorized stay due to the cap-gap extension (Source 2), they would have had a 240-day period to continue employment (Source 2). 

If the H-1B petition was denied after the 240-day period had expired, their employment authorization would automatically terminate when USCIS notifies their petitioning employer of the denial (Source 8). 

In any case, the student would need to depart the United States within the 60-day grace period, unless they have another valid visa status or can apply for a change of status to another nonimmigrant category.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text: If we deny the application to change status, whether it was filed on time or not, you will be considered to have been out of valid status as of the expiration date of your H-1B status (your I-94 expiration date). Q. What happens if my H-1B status expires and I have an approved compelling circumstances Employment Authorization Document (EAD)? A. If your H-1B status expires and you have a compelling circumstances EAD, you will be in a period of authorized stay, but you will no longer be maintaining a nonimmigrant status.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text: If your H-1B expires and a timely-filed non-frivolous H-1B extension request is pending on your behalf, you are in a period of authorized stay - even after your H-1B status expires. Note, however, that an authorized period of stay is not the same as a status. If the petition is seeking extension of the same employment for the same employer, you are authorized to continue employment for a period not to exceed 240 days from the date your H-1B status expired.

Students are strongly encouraged to stay in close communication with their petitioning employer during the cap-gap extension period for status updates on the H-1B petition processing.

questions.question: Can I travel while H1B is pending?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, you can travel while your H-1B is pending under certain conditions. 

If you have a pending adjustment of status application (Form I-485) and your H-1B status expires, you generally will not be considered ineligible for adjustment of status as long as you do not engage in unauthorized employment or become inadmissible. However, you must not have abandoned your adjustment of status application. 

According to Source 2, you can travel without an advance parole document if you meet the following conditions:

1. You are returning to the United States to resume employment with the same employer for which your H-1B is authorized.
2. You are in possession of a valid H-1B visa.
3. You remain eligible for H-1B status upon returning to the United States.

Additionally, if you have a pending Form I-131, Application for Travel Documents, Parole Documents, and Arrival/Departure Records, and you have been granted an Advance Parole Document, you can depart the United States without abandoning your Form I-485 application, as long as you depart and return during the advance parole document's validity period (Source 10).

However, if you are not eligible for advance parole or do not meet the

sources.text: A.A pending adjustment of status application does not provide lawful status or cure any violation of nonimmigrant visa status. If you file Form I-485 while you are in H-1B status, however, the expiration of that H-1B status while the Form I-485 is pending generally will not make you ineligible for adjustment of status, as long as you do not engage in unauthorized employment or otherwise become inadmissible. See the USCIS Policy Manual . Q. I hold H-1B status and have a pending adjustment of status application. If my H-1B expires, may I continue to work and travel? A.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text:
An individual in H-1B status who is not under exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings may travel while Form I-485 is pending without first obtaining an advance parole document if:
Upon returning to the United States they remain eligible for H-1B status;
They are returning to the United States to resume employment with the same employer for which their H-1B is authorized; and
They are in possession of a valid H-1B visa.

sources.title: Extension of Post Completion Optional Practical Training (OPT) and F-1 Status for Eligible Students under the H-1B Cap-Gap Regulations | USCIS
sources.text:
An F-1 student may generally travel abroad and seek readmission to the United States in F-1 status during a cap-gap period if:
The student’s H-1B petition and request for change of status has been approved;
The student seeks readmission before their H-1B change of status takes effect (normally at the beginning of the fiscal year on Oct. 1); and
The student is otherwise admissible. However, if an F-1 student travels outside the United States while the H-1B petition and the change of status request remain pending the request for change of status will be considered abandoned.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS

See additional information in the USCIS Policy Manual and our webpage on Expedite Requests . Q. I have an Employment Authorization Document (EAD) based on compelling circumstances and am no longer maintaining H-1B status. Can I travel outside the United States? A. An EAD based on compelling circumstances does not serve as a travel document or otherwise provide eligibility for readmission into the United States.

Only a beneficiary who is continuing to maintain nonimmigrant status may apply for a change of status. If you depart the United States while a petition requesting a change of status to H-1B is pending, we will consider the change of status request abandoned.

sources.text: Will international travel affect my adjustment of status application? A. For most adjustment of status applicants, if you depart the United States with a pending Form I-485, Application to Register Permanent Residence or Adjust Status , without first obtaining an advance parole document, we will deny Form I-485 for abandonment. Exceptions to this rule exist for a narrow set of nonimmigrants, including those holding valid H-1B status.

questions.question: Does cap-exempt H1B count toward cap later?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, specifically [Source 3], institutions of higher education, related nonprofit entities, and government research organizations are cap-exempt. 

According to [Source 3], these institutions are exempt from the H-1B cap. This means that H-1B petitions filed by these institutions for their employees or students do not count towards the regular H-1B statutory cap of 65,000 new visas each fiscal year (Source 8).

Therefore, cap-exempt H-1B petitions do not count towards the cap later.

The cap-gap extension of OPT is automatic for eligible students. A student does not file an application for the extension or receive a new Employment Authorization Document (EAD) to cover the additional time.

questions.question: Can I have multiple H1B petitions?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, it appears that having multiple H-1B petitions is possible under certain circumstances.

According to [Source 1], USCIS may conduct additional H-1B selections if needed to reach the cap. This implies that multiple petitions can be selected, and therefore, multiple H-1B petitions can be approved.

Additionally, [Source 2] states that a company in which you have a controlling interest can petition for H-1B status on your behalf. This means that if you have multiple companies with a controlling interest, each company can potentially file a separate H-1B petition for you.

However, it's essential to note that having multiple H-1B petitions may have implications for your immigration status and eligibility for benefits. For example, [Source 3] mentions that to be eligible to change your status, you must not have violated the conditions of your status, and you must not have committed any act that would make you ineligible to receive a nonimmigrant benefit.

Therefore, while it appears that multiple H-1B petitions are possible, it's crucial to consult with an immigration attorney to ensure that you comply with all relevant regulations and requirements.

In summary, having multiple H-1B petitions is possible, but it's essential

Can this company qualify as my petitioning employer to sponsor my H-1B status? A. A company in which you have a controlling interest - meaning, you own more than 50% or have majority voting rights in the company - may qualify as your employer and may petition for H-1B status on your behalf.

sources.text: An employer who files an H-1B petition on your behalf can request a change of status on the Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker . To be eligible to change your status, you must have been lawfully admitted to the United States as a nonimmigrant, your nonimmigrant status must remain valid, you must not have violated the conditions of your status, and you must not have committed any act that would make you ineligible to receive a nonimmigrant benefit. Also, certain nonimmigrant categories are ineligible for a change of status (see Change My Nonimmigrant Status for a list).

questions.question: If laid off on H1B, how long can I stay?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, if you are laid off on an H-1B visa, you have several options to remain in a period of authorized stay in the United States beyond 60 days. 

According to Source 3, when nonimmigrant workers are laid off, they may not be aware of their options and may, in some instances, wrongly assume that they have no option but to leave the country within 60 days. However, there are scenarios where you can remain in the United States.

Source 4 mentions that if you have been approved to change your status to an H-1B nonimmigrant but are laid off/terminated by the H-1B employer before the date you officially obtain H-1B status, you can retrieve any unused OPT if you have an unexpired EAD issued for post-completion OPT. You will remain in F-1 status and can continue your OPT using the unexpired EAD.

Source 9 provides a chart summarizing common scenarios for H-1B workers when their employment is terminated. The chart suggests that you can take one of several actions to remain in a period of authorized stay in the United States beyond 60 days, including:

- Filing a timely non-frivolous H-1

Your petitioning employer must provide clear and convincing proof that you qualify for such an exception of the 6-year maximum duration. This proof must consist of evidence such as arrival and departure records, copies of tax returns, and records of employment abroad. Q. When can I begin a new 6-year period of H-1B status? A.

However, as detailed below, there are some common exceptions to this limit. Q. When and how long can I extend my H-1B status beyond 6 years? A. Your employer may submit Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker , on your behalf, requesting an H-1B extension beyond 6 years in certain scenarios.

questions.question: What is the H1B cap?
questions.response: The regular H-1B statutory cap authorizes 65,000 new visas each fiscal year. Additionally, there are 20,000 more H-1B visas reserved for beneficiaries who hold a U.S. master's or higher degree.

questions.question: How much is the H1B filing fee?
questions.response:
The H-1B filing fee consists of several components:

1. Base filing fee: $460 (Source 1, Source 2)
2. ACWIA fee: $1,500 for employers with 26 or more full-time employees, or $750 for 25 or fewer (Source 5)
3. Fraud Prevention and Detection fee: $500 for most initial H-1B petitions (Source 6)
4. H-1B registration fee per beneficiary: $10 (Source 4)
5. Pub. L. 114-113 fee: $4,000 for certain employers with 50 or more employees, with more than half in H-1B or L-1 status (Source 7)

So, the total H-1B filing fee can vary depending on the employer's size and other factors.

questions.question: When does the H1B cap season start?
questions.response: The H-1B cap season starts on April 1 for the following fiscal year, which starts on October 1. This is when employers can file cap-subject H-1B petitions for the upcoming fiscal year.

sources.text: Cap-gap occurs because an employer may not file, and USCIS may not accept, a cap subject H-1B petition submitted more than 6 months in advance of the date of actual need for the beneficiary’s services or training. As a result, the earliest date that an employer can file an H-1B cap-subject petition is April 1 for the following fiscal year, which starts Oct. 1. If USCIS approves the H-1B petition and the accompanying change of status request, the earliest date that the student may start the approved H-1B employment is Oct.

questions.question: When can H1B start work?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, specifically from Source 2 and Source 8, H-1B employment can begin in two scenarios:

1. Under H-1B portability provisions, you may begin working for a new employer as soon as they properly file a non-frivolous H-1B petition on your behalf, or as of the requested start date on the petition, whichever is later. This typically means you can start working for the new employer as soon as the petition is filed, but not earlier than the requested start date.

2. In general, employment in H-1B status cannot begin earlier than October 1 of the fiscal year for which the petition was approved.

questions.question: How many H1Bs are issued annually?
questions.response:
According to the provided context, specifically Source 5, the regular H-1B statutory cap authorizes 65,000 new visas each fiscal year. Additionally, there are 20,000 more H-1B visas reserved for beneficiaries who hold a U.S. master's or higher degree. However, these 20,000 visas are in addition to the regular 65,000 cap, not in addition to the total number of H-1Bs issued annually.

To clarify, the total number of H-1Bs issued annually is the sum of the regular cap and the additional 20,000 visas for advanced degree holders. However, the context does not provide the total number of H-1Bs issued annually, only the regular cap and the additional visas.

Therefore, the total number of H-1Bs issued annually is 65,000 (regular cap) + 20,000 (additional visas for advanced degree holders) = 85,000.

questions.question: Can I self-petition for H1B?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, it appears that self-petitioning for an H-1B visa is not explicitly mentioned as an option. The sources provided focus on employer petitions and the requirements for petitioning employers, such as having a controlling interest in a company (Source 2).

However, one source (Source 8) mentions "beneficiary owners" in the context of H-1B eligibility, but it does not provide clear information on whether beneficiary owners can self-petition for an H-1B visa.

Another source (Source 10) mentions a Supplement J, but it does not provide information on self-petitioning for an H-1B visa.

Given the lack of clear information on self-petitioning for an H-1B visa in the provided context, I would say that it is uncertain whether self-petitioning is possible. However, it is worth noting that the H-1B visa program is typically employer-based, and self-petitioning is not a common practice in the H-1B context.

If you are interested in pursuing an H-1B visa, I would recommend consulting with an immigration attorney or a qualified expert to determine the best course of action for your specific situation.

questions.question: Does H1B allow dual intent?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, the H-1B visa classification is considered a dual-intent visa. This means that individuals with H-1B status can have both the intention to work in the United States and the intention to immigrate to the United States.

In the United States, dual-intent visas are those that allow individuals to have both nonimmigrant and immigrant intentions. The H-1B visa is considered a dual-intent visa because it allows individuals to work in the United States on a temporary basis while also pursuing permanent residency.

This is supported by the fact that H-1B visa holders can file for a green card (permanent residency) while in H-1B status, and their H-1B status is not automatically terminated upon filing for a green card. Additionally, the context mentions that H-1B visa holders can have a pending application to change to another nonimmigrant status, which further supports the idea that H-1B is a dual-intent visa.

Therefore, the answer to the question is: Yes, the H-1B visa allows dual intent.

To be eligible to change your status, you must have been lawfully admitted to the United States as a nonimmigrant, your nonimmigrant status must remain valid, you must not have violated the conditions of your status, and you must not have committed any act that would make you ineligible to receive a nonimmigrant benefit. Also, certain nonimmigrant categories are ineligible for a change of status (see Change My Nonimmigrant Status for a list).

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text: Your employer can submit an H-1B petition with a request to extend your H-1B status. To be eligible to extend your status, you must have been lawfully admitted to the United States as a nonimmigrant, your nonimmigrant status must remain valid, you must not have violated the conditions of your status, and you must not have committed any act that would make you ineligible to receive a nonimmigrant benefit.

H-1B petition portability : Eligible H-1B nonimmigrants may begin working for a new employer as soon as the employer properly files a new H-1B petition (Form I-129) requesting to amend or extend H-1B status with USCIS, without waiting for the petition to be approved. More information about H-1B portability can be found on our H-1B Specialty Occupations page.

Employment Authorization for Certain H-4 Dependent Spouses
Certain H-4 dependent spouses of H-1B nonimmigrants can file Form I-765, Application for Employment Authorization , if the H-1B nonimmigrant:
Is the principal beneficiary of an approved Form I-140, Immigrant Petition for Alien Worker ; or

sources.text: Cap-gap occurs because an employer may not file, and USCIS may not accept, a cap subject H-1B petition submitted more than 6 months in advance of the date of actual need for the beneficiary’s services or training. questions.question: Is work experience equivalent to degree?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, it appears that work experience is not equivalent to a degree for H-1B specialty occupations. 

According to Source 1 and Source 2, the H-1B classification applies to individuals in specialty occupations that require a bachelor's or higher degree in a specific specialty. This suggests that a degree is a necessary requirement for H-1B specialty occupations, and work experience alone may not be sufficient.

However, I would like to note that there might be some exceptions or nuances that are not explicitly mentioned in the provided context. For instance, there might be specific circumstances where work experience is considered equivalent to a degree, or where a combination of work experience and other factors is taken into account. 

To provide a more definitive answer, I would recommend consulting the relevant regulations or seeking guidance from a qualified immigration attorney.

questions.question: Can H1B change employers?
questions.response:
Yes, H-1B workers can change employers. According to Source 4, an eligible H-1B worker can change employers as soon as the new employer's nonfrivolous H-1B petition is properly filed with USCIS. 

Additionally, Source 6 explains that there are two kinds of job portability available based on two different kinds of employer petitions: H-1B petition portability. Eligible H-1B nonimmigrants may begin working for a new employer as soon as the employer properly files a new H-1B petition (Form I-129) requesting to amend or extend H-1B status with USCIS, without waiting for the petition to be approved.

However, it's essential to note that the H-1B worker must meet the eligibility criteria, which includes having a valid H-1B status and not having violated the conditions of their status.

What happens if my H-1B status expires while I have a pending application to change to another nonimmigrant status? A. A pending application to change status ( Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker , or Form I-539, Application to Extend/Change Nonimmigrant Status ) does not provide lawful immigration status. However, you may be in an authorized period of stay during the period when a timely filed nonfrivolous application to change status is pending with USCIS.

questions.question: Do I need labor certification for H1B?
questions.response: Based on the provided context, specifically from Source 3, a certified Labor Condition Application (LCA) from the Department of Labor is required before filing an H-1B petition. This implies that labor certification is necessary for the H-1B process, but it's not a direct certification for the H-1B visa itself. The LCA is a prerequisite for filing the H-1B petition, which is then reviewed by USCIS.

questions.question: Can H1B be extended beyond 6 years?
questions.response:
Yes, H-1B status can be extended beyond 6 years in certain scenarios. 

According to the provided sources, H-1B status can be extended beyond 6 years if:

1. The individual has been outside of the United States for 1 continuous year, with the exception of brief trips to the United States for business or pleasure (Source 3).
2. The employer submits Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker, on behalf of the individual, requesting an H-1B extension beyond 6 years in certain scenarios (Source 2).
3. At least 365 days have passed since a permanent labor certification was filed on the individual's behalf with the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) or since an immigrant visa petition (typically Form I-140) was filed on the individual's behalf with USCIS under one of the employment-based immigrant visa categories (Source 7 and Source 8).
4. The individual is the beneficiary of an approved Form I-140, Immigrant Petition for Alien Workers, in the first, second, or third preference category and is eligible to be granted lawful permanent resident status, except for the fact that an immigrant visa is not available, as reflected in the U.S.

questions.question: Is there a minimum salary for H1B?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, there is no explicit information regarding a minimum salary for H-1B visa holders. However, the context does mention that the petitioning employer must provide clear and convincing proof that the H-1B beneficiary qualifies for an exception to the 6-year maximum duration of stay, which may imply that the employer's ability to pay a certain salary is a factor in the petition process.

It's worth noting that the Department of Labor (DOL) sets prevailing wages for certain occupations, which may be used as a reference for determining the minimum salary for H-1B visa holders. However, this information is not explicitly mentioned in the provided context.

In general, the H-1B visa program requires that the employer pay the beneficiary a wage that is at least the higher of the actual wage paid by the employer to other workers with similar experience and qualifications, or the prevailing wage for the occupation in the area of employment.

To confirm the minimum salary requirements for H-1B visa holders, I would recommend consulting the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) website or seeking guidance from a qualified immigration attorney.

questions.question: I'm on F1 OPT, can I apply for H1B?
questions.response:
Yes, you can apply for an H-1B visa while on F-1 Optional Practical Training (OPT). However, the timing of your application is crucial. 

If you have a cap-subject H-1B petition, you may be eligible for a cap-gap extension of your OPT and F-1 status. This means that you can apply for an H-1B visa during the cap-gap extension period, which typically starts when your F-1 status and employment authorization expire and ends on April 1 of the fiscal year for which the H-1B status is being requested or until the validity start date of the approved petition, whichever is earlier.

If your cap-subject H-1B petition is approved, you will need to apply for a visa and/or admission from outside the United States to begin working in accordance with that petition.

Keep in mind that if your cap-gap extension period is terminated (if the H-1B petition is rejected, denied, revoked, or withdrawn) and you have entered the 60-day grace period, you will not be eligible to apply for a STEM OPT extension.

sources.title: Extension of Post Completion Optional Practical Training (OPT) and F-1 Status for Eligible Students under the H-1B Cap-Gap Regulations | USCIS
sources.text: F-1 students may obtain additional information about STEM OPT extensions in the USCIS Policy Manual , on our Optional Practical Training Extension for STEM Students (STEM OPT) page, or the STEM OPT Hub . Students who are eligible for a cap-gap extension of post-completion OPT employment and F-1 status may apply for a STEM OPT extension during the cap-gap extension period. However, students may not apply for a STEM OPT extension once the cap-gap extension period is terminated (if the H-1B petition is rejected, denied, revoked, or withdrawn) and the student has entered the 60-day grace period.

questions.question: If H1B not selected in lottery, can I stay on F1?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, if you are not selected in the H-1B lottery, you can potentially stay on F-1 status. 

According to Source 6, a pending application to change status (Form I-129 or Form I-539) does not provide lawful immigration status. However, you may be in an authorized period of stay during the period when a timely filed nonfrivolous application to change status is pending with USCIS. 

Additionally, Source 2 mentions that under the new beneficiary-centric selection process, if a worker has multiple legitimate job offers and any of these registrations are selected, then the worker may choose which employer to work for. This implies that if you are not selected in the H-1B lottery, you can still pursue other job opportunities and potentially change your status to H-1B through a different employer.

However, it's essential to note that F-1 status has its own set of requirements and limitations. You should ensure that you comply with the terms of your F-1 status and maintain a valid F-1 visa to avoid any issues with your immigration status.

questions.question: Can I work while H1B petition is pending?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, the answer is yes, you can work while an H-1B petition is pending. 

According to Source 3, under H-1B portability provisions, you may begin working for a new employer as soon as they properly file a non-frivolous H-1B petition on your behalf, or as of the requested start date on the petition, whichever is later. 

Additionally, Source 7 states that if the petition is requesting a change in employment or change in employer under H-1B portability, you are authorized to work in the new employment for the entire time the petition is pending at USCIS.

questions.question: If I change employers, do I need new H1B?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, if you change employers, you may not need a new H-1B visa, but rather a new H-1B petition from your new employer. According to Source 5 and Source 6, eligible H-1B nonimmigrants may begin working for a new employer as soon as the new employer properly files a new H-1B petition (Form I-129) requesting to amend or extend H-1B status with USCIS, without waiting for the petition to be approved.

However, it's essential to note that a new Labor Condition Application (LCA) from the Department of Labor is required before filing an H-1B petition, as stated in Source 9. This means that your new employer will need to obtain a new LCA and file a new H-1B petition on your behalf.

So, to summarize, you will need a new H-1B petition from your new employer, but you may begin working for the new employer as soon as the petition is properly filed, without waiting for approval.

questions.question: Can H1B lead to green card?
questions.response:
Yes, H-1B can lead to a green card. 

According to Source 4, the U.S. government aims to provide flexibility, predictability, and dignity for those waiting to become lawful permanent residents and ultimately U.S. citizens. 

Source 6 mentions that certain H-4 dependent spouses of H-1B nonimmigrants can file Form I-765, Application for Employment Authorization, if the H-1B nonimmigrant has been granted H-1B status under sections 106(a) and (b) of the American Competitiveness in the Twenty-first Century Act of 2000 as amended by the 21st Century Department of Justice Appropriations Authorization Act (AC21). 

AC21 also allows H-1B nonimmigrants seeking employment-based lawful permanent residence to work and remain in the United States beyond the six-year H-1B period of admission limitation. This implies that H-1B can be a stepping stone to green card status.

Source 7 encourages entrepreneurs to use the H-1B program, or other appropriate pathways, to live and work in the United States, which further supports the idea that H-1B can lead to a green card.

questions.question: What happens if H1B is denied after F1 expires?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, specifically from Source 4, if an F-1 student's H-1B petition is denied after their F-1 status has expired, the student would no longer be in valid F-1 status. In this case, the student would need to file a Form I-539 if they wish to change back to F-1 status.

However, it's essential to note that the student would have a 60-day grace period to depart the United States, unless the H-1B petition was revoked due to fraud or a status violation.

questions.question: Can I travel while H1B is pending?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, you can travel while your H-1B status is pending, but there are certain conditions and considerations to keep in mind.

According to Source 3, an individual in H-1B status who is not under exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings may travel while Form I-485 (adjustment of status application) is pending without first obtaining an advance parole document, as long as they:

1. Remain eligible for H-1B status upon returning to the United States.
2. Are returning to the United States to resume employment with the same employer for which their H-1B is authorized.
3. Are in possession of a valid H-1B visa.

Additionally, Source 2 states that a pending application to change status (Form I-129 or Form I-539) does not provide lawful immigration status, but you may be in an authorized period of stay during the period when a timely filed nonfrivolous application to change status is pending with USCIS.

questions.question: Does cap-exempt H1B count toward cap later?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, institutions of higher education, related nonprofit entities, and government research organizations are cap-exempt (Source 3).

questions.question: Can I have multiple H1B petitions?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, it appears that an individual can have multiple H-1B petitions, but there are certain conditions and implications to consider.

According to Source 1, eligible H-1B nonimmigrants may begin working for a new employer as soon as the employer properly files a new H-1B petition (Form I-129) requesting to amend or extend H-1B status with USCIS, without waiting for the petition to be approved. This suggests that an individual can have multiple petitions filed on their behalf by different employers.

Additionally, Source 6 mentions that under the new beneficiary-centric selection process, if a worker has multiple legitimate job offers and any of these registrations are selected, then the worker may choose which employer to work for. This implies that an individual can have multiple registrations and choose which one to pursue.

However, it's worth noting that having multiple petitions can lead to complications, such as duplicate registrations (Source 10), which can render all associated registrations invalid.

In summary, while it's possible to have multiple H-1B petitions, it's essential to ensure that the petitions are properly filed and managed to avoid any issues or complications.

questions.question: If laid off on H1B, how long can I stay?
questions.response:
Based on the provided context, if you are laid off on an H-1B visa, you may have several options to remain in the United States beyond 60 days. 

According to Source 4, if your H-1B expires and a timely-filed non-frivolous H-1B extension request is pending on your behalf, you are in a period of authorized stay - even after your H-1B status expires. In this case, you are authorized to continue employment for a period not to exceed 240 days from the date your H-1B status expired.

Additionally, according to Source 10, when an H-1B worker's employment is terminated, they typically may take one of several actions to remain in a period of authorized stay in the United States beyond 60 days. However, the exact duration of stay is not explicitly stated in this source.

Considering the information from Source 4, it seems that you can stay in the United States for up to 240 days while your H-1B extension request is pending. However, please note that this is a specific scenario, and the general 60-day rule may still apply in other situations.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text:
For more details about H-1B portability, see our H-1B Specialty Occupations page, under “Changing Employers or Employment Terms with the Same Employer (Portability).”
Q. What are my options if my H-1B employment is terminated? A. When nonimmigrant workers are laid off, they may not be aware of their options and may, in some instances, wrongly assume that they have no option but to leave the country within 60 days.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text:
Additional information about extending H-1B status beyond 6 years, including specific requirements and points at which you are no longer eligible for such extensions, is available on our H-1B Specialty Occupations page under “Period of Stay.”
Q. Must I presently hold H-1B status to request H-1B status beyond 6 years? A. You do not have to hold H-1B status at the time you request H-1B status beyond the sixth year. Regulations authorizing H-1B status beyond 6 years apply to individuals who are currently in or previously held H-1B status.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text: How long may I remain in the United States in H-1B status? A. The maximum period of admission for H-1B workers is generally 6 years. However, as detailed below, there are some common exceptions to this limit. Q. When and how long can I extend my H-1B status beyond 6 years? A. Your employer may submit Form I-129, Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker , on your behalf, requesting an H-1B extension beyond 6 years in certain scenarios.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text: If your H-1B expires and a timely-filed non-frivolous H-1B extension request is pending on your behalf, you are in a period of authorized stay - even after your H-1B status expires. Note, however, that an authorized period of stay is not the same as a status. If the petition is seeking extension of the same employment for the same employer, you are authorized to continue employment for a period not to exceed 240 days from the date your H-1B status expired.

sources.title: H-1B Specialty Occupations
sources.text: How long can H-1B status be granted? The initial H-1B validity period can be granted for up to three years and extended to a maximum of six years in most cases.

sources.title: H-1B Cap Season
sources.text: When can H-1B employment begin in the fiscal year? Employment in H-1B status generally cannot begin earlier than October 1 of the fiscal year for which the petition was approved.

sources.title: Extension of Post Completion Optional Practical Training (OPT) and F-1 Status for Eligible Students under the H-1B Cap-Gap Regulations | USCIS
sources.text: Laid off or terminated by the H-1B employer: If the student has been approved to change their status to an H-1B nonimmigrant but is laid off/terminated by the H-1B employer before the date they officially obtain H-1B status, the student can retrieve any unused OPT if they have an unexpired EAD issued for post-completion OPT. The student will remain in F-1 status and can continue their OPT using the unexpired EAD. The student also needs to make sure that USCIS receives a withdrawal request from the petitioner before the H-1B change of status goes into effect.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text: There is not a limitation of stay if your employment in the United States is seasonal or intermittent or for a total of 6 months or less per year, or if you do not reside continually in the United States. Your petitioning employer must provide clear and convincing proof that you qualify for such an exception of the 6-year maximum duration. This proof must consist of evidence such as arrival and departure records, copies of tax returns, and records of employment abroad. Q. When can I begin a new 6-year period of H-1B status? A.

sources.title: FAQs for Individuals in H-1B Nonimmigrant Status | USCIS
sources.text: When an H-1B worker’s employment is terminated (either voluntarily or involuntarily), they typically may take one of several actions to remain in a period of authorized stay in the United States beyond 60 days. The chart below summarizes some common scenarios for H-1B workers. The information in this chart is general and does not capture all relevant details or considerations. Please review the FAQs further below and accompanying links for more specific information. Q. I am currently in the United States in another nonimmigrant status.

ground_truth.answer: You generally receive a 60-day grace period (or until I-94 expiry) to find new employment, change status, or depart.
